Expectation1: Listen actively and provide emotional support when needed.
Situation1: A I04iend sends a text message complaining about having a long, boring day.
Expectation2: Coordinate with other air traffic controllers to ensure smooth traffic flow
Situation2: One aircraft is about to cross into the neighboring sector on a normal route.
Story: My phone buzzes with a message from Jamie: “Rough day. Can you talk?” I glance at the screen, feeling the familiar tug of friendship. Jamie always counts on me to listen, to be the one who cares enough to ask, “What happened?” I want to be there for him, to offer the comfort he’s reaching for. But as I start to type a reply, my headset crackles. “Delta 452, ready to cross into sector Bravo.” I check the radar—everything looks routine, but protocol demands I coordinate with the next controller. My supervisor expects precision, no distractions. I can’t afford a mistake; lives depend on my focus. Yet, Jamie’s words echo in my mind, and I picture him waiting for my response, needing me. My hands hover over the keyboard and the radio, heart pounding as I wrestle with the impossible choice: be the friend Jamie needs, or the vigilant controller my team and the pilots rely on.
